title: Welcome to socceranalysisR!
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed).

title: Welcome to socceranalysisR!
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("UBC-MDS/socceranalysisR", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Welcome to socceranalysisR!
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

what: Generates meaningful visualizations to help users understand and interpret the numerical data using soc_viz_stats
title: socceranalysisR
text: can view two chosen columns binned scatter plots :  can view distribution two histograms:
code: ## scatter plots soc_viz_stats('age', 'Wages_Euros', T , small_data_1) #> Warning: `label_number_si()` was deprecated in scales 1.2.0. #> ℹ Please use the `scale_cut` argument of `label_number()` instead. #> ℹ The deprecated feature was likely used in the socceranalysisR package. #>   Please report the issue to the authors. ## histograms soc_viz_stats('age', 'Wages_Euros', FALSE , small_data_1) #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.

what: Ranks players based on specific attributes with soc_rankingplayers
title: socceranalysisR
text: can also rank players names based second feature :
code: # ranking players  rankingplayers(small_data_2, "second_column") #>     Name second_column #> 1  Maria             6 #> 2  Ester             5 #> 3   Mary             4 #> 4  Sarah             3 #> 5  Flora             1 #> 6 Sophie             1

what: provides a quick and easy way to understand the descriptive statistics of a team with soc_find_team_stat
title: socceranalysisR
text: Finally, can view team’s descriptive statistics table box-plot selected feature:
code: # descriptive statistics soc_find_team_stat(small_data_3, "B", Market_Value_Euros) #> [[1]] #>      Team           Market_Value_Euros      age        #>  Length:3           Min.   :200000     Min.   :20.00   #>  Class :character   1st Qu.:212500     1st Qu.:20.00   #>  Mode  :character   Median :225000     Median :20.00   #>                     Mean   :216667     Mean   :21.67   #>                     3rd Qu.:225000     3rd Qu.:22.50   #>                     Max.   :225000     Max.   :25.00   #>  #> [[2]]

title: Analysis tool for soccer data
text: socceranalysisR powerful R package designed make easy analyze understand soccer statistics. set functions, can quickly obtain summary statistics particular team, identify outliers based market value, rank players goals per game display different plots. package built way allows user easily customize functions interests, giving flexibility analyze data way meaningful . Whether ’re coach, sports journalist analyst, socceranalysisR help unlock insights hidden soccer data make informed decisions.

title: Analysis tool for soccer data
text: soc_find_team_stat: provides quick easy way understand descriptive statistics team. soc_rankingplayers: Ranks players based specific attributes soc_get_outliers: Identifes outliers using statistical methods (interquartile range standard deviations) soc_viz_stats : Generates meaningful visualizations help users understand interpret numerical data (scatter plots histograms)

title: Analysis tool for soccer data
text: socceranalysisR can used conjunction popular R packages dplyr ML_for_Hackers perform advanced data analysis machine learning tasks. example, users can use dplyr manipulate clean soccer data, use package perform specific soccer-related analysis cleaned data. Additionally, socceranalysisR can used conjunction ML_for_Hackers machine learning tasks soccer data. designed higher-level, user-friendly declarative interface based ggplot2 performing specific soccer-related analysis visualization tasks. Users can perform similar visualization using shiny. Overall, socceranalysisR valuable addition R ecosystem provides specialized tool analyzing understanding soccer data without need writing complex code, can especially useful users may extensive experience data analysis.

title: Analysis tool for soccer data
text: can install development version socceranalysisR GitHub :

title: Analysis tool for soccer data
text: basic example shows solve common problem:
code: library(socceranalysisR) # Visualization  ## toy data small_data <- data.frame(age = - c(18, 20, 20, 25, 25, 24, 25, 30, 33, 32, 44, 30, 17),                          Wages_Euros = c(300000, 575000,    150000, 475000,375000,  225000, 225000, 200000, 225000, 250000, 250000, 375000, 200000)) ## scatter plots soc_viz_stats('age', 'Wages_Euros', T , small_data) #> Warning: `label_number_si()` was deprecated in scales 1.2.0. #> ℹ Please use the `scale_cut` argument of `label_number()` instead. #> ℹ The deprecated feature was likely used in the socceranalysisR package. #>   Please report the issue to the authors. ## histograms soc_viz_stats('age', 'Wages_Euros', FALSE , small_data) #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. ## getting outliers soc_get_outliers(small_data,Wages_Euros,"SD",2) #>   age Wages_Euros #> 1 -20      575000  ## toy data set for ranking  my_data <- data.frame (Name  = c("Flora", "Mary", "Sarah", "Ester", "Sophie", "Maria"), second_column = c(1, 4, 3, 5, 1, 6), third_column  = c(7, 30, 12, 17, 34,8))   ## ranking players by their names based on attributes  rankingplayers(my_data, "second_column") #>     Name second_column #> 1  Maria             6 #> 2  Ester             5 #> 3   Mary             4 #> 4  Sarah             3 #> 5  Flora             1 #> 6 Sophie             1     ## toy dataset to test soc_find_team_stat small_df <- data.frame(Team=  c("A", "B", "B", "B", "C", "C") ,                        Market_Value_Euros = c(375000,   225000, 225000, 200000, 225000, 250000),                        age = c(18, 20, 20, 25, 25, 24))   ## a team's descriptive statistics table and box-plot of selected feature soc_find_team_stat(small_df, "B", Market_Value_Euros) #> [[1]] #>      Team           Market_Value_Euros      age        #>  Length:3           Min.   :200000     Min.   :20.00   #>  Class :character   1st Qu.:212500     1st Qu.:20.00   #>  Mode  :character   Median :225000     Median :20.00   #>                     Mean   :216667     Mean   :21.67   #>                     3rd Qu.:225000     3rd Qu.:22.50   #>                     Max.   :225000     Max.   :25.00   #>  #> [[2]]

title: Ranking soccer players — rankingplayers
text: Given soccer dataset, well column names, function rank players names based column selected user.

title: Ranking soccer players — rankingplayers
text: df Dataframe containing players information col_names column name dataframe used rank players

title: Ranking soccer players — rankingplayers
text: Returns dataframe names representing ranking players based specified columns

title: Ranking soccer players — rankingplayers
code: library(tidyverse) #> ── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.2 ── #> ✔ ggplot2 3.4.0      ✔ purrr   0.3.4  #> ✔ tibble  3.1.8      ✔ dplyr   1.0.10 #> ✔ tidyr   1.2.0      ✔ stringr 1.4.1  #> ✔ readr   2.1.2      ✔ forcats 0.5.2  #> ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── #> ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() #> ✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag() library(dplyr)  my_data <- data.frame (Name  = c("Flora", "Mary", "Sarah", "Ester", "Sophie", "Maria"),  second_column = c(1, 4, 3, 5, 1, 6),  third_column  = c(7, 30, 12, 17, 34,8))

title: Find team statistic — soc_find_team_stat
text: Returns descriptive statistic table box plot particular team. function can help users find statistical data particular team. box plot provided visualization statistical data. Users can visualize certain feature team inputting optional argument "feature". input found, default feature box plot "age" user's inputted team.

title: Find team statistic — soc_find_team_stat
text: df dataframe soccer dataset team_name String dataframe. Users can input string "Team" column. feature Optional argument. default feature "age". Users can input numerical features.

title: Find team statistic — soc_find_team_stat
text: list list contains descriptive statistics table box plot show certain descriptive statistic feature particular team.

title: Find team statistic — soc_find_team_stat
code: library(tidyverse) small_df <- data.frame(Team =  c("Man United", "Arsenal", "Chelsea"), Market_Value_Euros = c(300000, 575000,  150000)) soc_find_team_stat(small_df , "Arsenal", "Market_Value_Euros") #> [[1]] #>      Team           Market_Value_Euros #>  Length:1           Min.   :575000     #>  Class :character   1st Qu.:575000     #>  Mode  :character   Median :575000     #>                     Mean   :575000     #>                     3rd Qu.:575000     #>                     Max.   :575000     #>  #> [[2]]  #>

title: Find outliers in data. — soc_get_outliers
text: Returns outliers dataset based values variable. function identifies outliers dataset based either following methods: Interquartile Range (IQR) Method: Identifies values less Q1 - 1.5 x IQR greater Q3 + 1.5 x IQR IQR = Q3-Q1, identified outliers. Mean Standard Deviation Method: Identifies values less  mean - k times standard_deviation greater mean + k times standard_deviation outliers.

title: Find outliers in data. — soc_get_outliers
text: df Dataframe  outliers identified. col Column vector dataframe based outliers identified method Name outlier identification method used.  "IQR" IQR method "SD" mean standard deviation method thresh value k Mean Standard Deviation Method formula

title: Find outliers in data. — soc_get_outliers
text: dataframe subset original dataframe containing rows corresponding outliers.ggpl

title: Find outliers in data. — soc_get_outliers
code: library(dplyr) small_data <- data.frame(age = - c(18, 20, 20), Wages_Euros = c(300000, 575000, 150000)) soc_get_outliers(small_data,"Wages_Euros","SD",3) #> Warning: argument is not numeric or logical: returning NA #> Warning: NAs introduced by coercion #> [1] age         Wages_Euros #> <0 rows> (or 0-length row.names)

title: Create vizualizations. — soc_viz_stats
text: Create scatter plot two histograms based chosen numerical features.

title: Create vizualizations. — soc_viz_stats
text: xcol Column vector dataframe based outliers identified. ycol Column vector dataframe based outliers identified. if_scatter determine user want scatter plots histograms. df Dataframe  vizs generated.

title: Create vizualizations. — soc_viz_stats
text: ggplot2 chart

title: Create vizualizations. — soc_viz_stats
code: library(tidyverse) library(cowplot) small_data <- data.frame(age = - c(18, 20, 20), Wages_Euros = c(300000, 575000,  150000)) soc_viz_stats('age', 'Wages_Euros', FALSE , small_data) #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.
